input:
2. A 29-year-old female presents with a three-year history of progressive gait instability and frequent falls, along with difficulty coordinating her hands during fine motor tasks such as buttoning clothes. She also notes intermittent dizziness and mild dysarthria that have gradually worsened over time. There is no reported sensory disturbance or muscle weakness, but her family history is notable for her paternal uncle having a similar neurodegenerative condition diagnosed in his early 30s. On examination, she displays a wide-based ataxic gait, intention tremor, and impaired tandem walking, along with saccadic pursuit and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Cerebellar testing reveals dysdiadochokinesia and an inability to perform accurate heel-to-shin maneuvers. Brain MRI shows pronounced cerebellar cortical atrophy, predominantly involving the hemispheres. Genetic analysis identifies a pathogenic variant in the FAT2 gene, confirming the diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia 45. Symptomatic treatment with coordination training and speech therapy has been recommended to optimize her quality of life.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: The patient should explain her symptoms in a way that shows she's been struggling with her coordination and balance for a while, but she might be unsure about what it all means. She might feel a bit overwhelmed or worried, so her response should reflect uncertainty and concern without sounding overly confident or knowing the medical details.  
ANSWER: Um, I guess I've just been feeling more unsteady when I walk and I keep falling more often than before. It’s been happening over the last few years, and I keep noticing that I can’t do things like buttoning my clothes very well anymore. I’m kind of scared because it’s been getting worse, and I don’t really understand why.

She also notes intermittent dizziness and mild dysarthria that have gradually worsened over time. There is no reported sensory disturbance or muscle weakness, but her family history is notable for her paternal uncle having a similar neurodegenerative condition diagnosed in his early 30s. On examination, she displays a wide-based ataxic gait, intention tremor, and impaired tandem walking, along with saccadic pursuit and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Cerebellar testing reveals dysdiadochokinesia and an inability to perform accurate heel-to-shin maneuvers. Brain MRI shows pronounced cerebellar cortical atrophy, predominantly involving the hemispheres. Genetic analysis identifies a pathogenic variant in the FAT2 gene, confirming the diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia 45. Symptomatic treatment with coordination training and speech therapy has been recommended to optimize her quality of life.Can you tell me more about how your symptoms have been affecting your daily routines and if you've noticed any other changes, like in your memory, mood, or bladder control?
output: Well, it’s been hard to do things like, you know, button my clothes or pick things up without losing my balance sometimes, and I feel like I’m getting more clumsy. I haven't really noticed anything with my memory or moods that stand out, but I get really dizzy sometimes, and I worry about, um, if I might forget stuff, though I’m not sure. I just feel more shaky and off than before.

input: 2. A 29-year-old female presents with a three-year history of progressive gait instability and frequent falls, along with difficulty coordinating her hands during fine motor tasks such as buttoning clothes. She also notes intermittent dizziness and mild dysarthria that have gradually worsened over time. There is no reported sensory disturbance or muscle weakness, but her family history is notable for her paternal uncle having a similar neurodegenerative condition diagnosed in his early 30s. On examination, she displays a wide-based ataxic gait, intention tremor, and impaired tandem walking, along with saccadic pursuit and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Cerebellar testing reveals dysdiadochokinesia and an inability to perform accurate heel-to-shin maneuvers. Brain MRI shows pronounced cerebellar cortical atrophy, predominantly involving the hemispheres. Genetic analysis identifies a pathogenic variant in the FAT2 gene, confirming the diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia 45. Symptomatic treatment with coordination training and speech therapy has been recommended to optimize her quality of life.Can you describe how your symptoms have changed over the past few years, and have you noticed any new issues or symptoms, such as problems with your vision, speech, swallowing, or any autonomic symptoms like blood pressure changes or urinary problems?
output: Um, well, I guess it’s been a little worse, especially with walking and trying to do things like buttons or even just holding a cup seems harder now. I think my speech has gotten a little more slurred and I feel kinda dizzy more often, like off-balance. I don’t really know about swallowing or if my eyes are doing something weird, but sometimes my vision feels a little blurry when I move my head. And I haven’t noticed anything about blood pressure or going to the bathroom differently, I don’t think.

There is no reported sensory disturbance or muscle weakness, but her family history is notable for her paternal uncle having a similar neurodegenerative condition diagnosed in his early 30s. On examination, she displays a wide-based ataxic gait, intention tremor, and impaired tandem walking, along with saccadic pursuit and gaze-evoked nystagmus. Cerebellar testing reveals dysdiadochokinesia and an inability to perform accurate heel-to-shin maneuvers. Brain MRI shows pronounced cerebellar cortical atrophy, predominantly involving the hemispheres. Genetic analysis identifies a pathogenic variant in the FAT2 gene, confirming the diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia 45. Symptomatic treatment with coordination training and speech therapy has been recommended to optimize her quality of life.Have you experienced any episodes of sudden blood pressure drops, fainting, or significant fluctuations in blood pressure, especially when standing up? Additionally, can you describe the pattern and extent of your urinary frequency or urgency—has it changed recently or been persistent over time?
output: Um, I don’t think I’ve really noticed any sudden drops or anything like that, like I suddenly feeling really faint. Sometimes I stand up and everything kinda spins for a second, but I’ve not really tracked blood pressure or anything. As for the urinary stuff, I do feel like I go to the bathroom more often, and sometimes I can’t really hold it—like, I guess I have to go more than I used to, and it’s been like this for a while now.
